video-config.troubleshootingIntro: If you're having any trouble getting your webcam set up, please feel free to email Vivian Han at vivhan@mit.edu and we'd be glad to help you out!

video-consent.purpose: Children have an amazing ability to learn new concepts from very little information. When learning a new category, they only need to see a few examples to understand what kinds of things that category encompasses and to generalize to other instances of that category. In this study, we want to explore how children use definitions and examples to learn about very broad categories (e.g. 'mammals').
video-consent.procedures: This study takes about 15 minutes. During this study your child will learn about 4 different animal categories. For each trial, you will see a short video definition and a few examples of animals in a specific category, then answer a question regarding the category.
video-consent.risk_statement: There are no expected risks if you participate in the study.
video-consent.payment: After you finish the study, we will email you a $5 Amazon gift card (via a code that can be entered online) within five days to thank you for your time. To be eligible for the gift card your child must be in the age range for this study, you need to submit a valid consent statement, and we need to see that there is a child with you. But we will send a gift card even if you do not finish the whole study or we are not able to use your child's data! There are no other direct benefits to you or your child from participating, but we hope you will enjoy the experience.
video-consent.research_rights_statement: You are not waiving any legal claims, rights or remedies because of your participation in this research study.  If you feel you have been treated unfairly, or you have questions regarding your rights as a research subject, you may contact the Committee On the Use of Humans as Experimental Subjects (COUHES), Massachusetts of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Avenue Cambridge, MA 02139 (contact: couhes@mit.edu)

video-quality.title: Webcam setup for the study
video-quality.introText: Please check each of the following to ensure we're able to use your video:

instructionBlocks.text: Make sure the webcam you're using is roughly centered relative to this monitor. This makes it much easier for us to tell whether your child is pointing to the left or right!

image.alt: Example images of using centered external webcam on monitor or built-in webcam on laptop.

instructionBlocks.text: Turn off any other monitors connected to your computer, besides the one with the centered webcam. (If there's just one monitor, you're all set!)

image.alt: Example images showing laptop screen turned off if using external monitor and webcam, or external monitor turned off if using built-in webcam and laptop screen.

instructionBlocks.text: Check the lighting by making sure you can clearly see your own eyes on the webcam view to the right. You may need to either turn on a light or reduce light coming from behind you.

image.alt: Example images showing good lighting, room too dark, and backlit scene where eyes are not visible.

instructionBlocks.text: If it's practical, minimize exciting things that are visible behind or to the side of the screen--for instance, by facing a wall instead of the kitchen. (If this isn't practical for you, don't worry about it--just check the box!)

image.alt: Example images showing a child and puppy next to the computer, versus a computer just on its own.

video-quality.recordingInstructionText: You should be able to see your camera view above.

blocks.text: Please try playing this sample audio to make sure you'll be able to hear the story.
blocks.title: Adjust your speakers

mediaBlock.warningText: Please try playing the sample audio.

webcamBlocks.title: Make sure we can see you

listblocks.text: Take a look at your webcam view above. Get comfy, and adjust your own position or the computer as needed so both you and your child are visible.

This isn't a Skype call - no one in the lab can see you - but the recorded video of your participation will be sent to the lab to help with data analysis. It's helpful for us to be able to see if your child was pointing or looking confused, for example.

blocks.text: Hello! Thank you so much for participating in our study. We'll start by walking through one trial together. In this example trial, we'll be learning about dogs.

Next, you will help us show your child a few examples of dogs. On the next slide, there will be a grid of animals. Four pictures of dogs will be highlighted. Please point at each highlighted animal, name it, and explain to your child that it is in the category. We'll first demonstrate what we'd like you to do for the first three examples. Then, we'll ask you to do the same for the last animal.

parentTextBlock.text: Please point at each highlighted animal, name it, and explain to your child that it is in the category. For example, 'Look over here. This is a dalmatian. A dalmatian is a dog.
parentTextBlock.title: Parent's task

blocks.text: Now, we're going to ask your child whether a specific animal is in the category. Your child can respond by clicking the button for yes or no. If your child cannot click the answer, they can point or respond verbally and you can click for them.

However, please let your child respond on their own and do not try to influence your child's answer. We understand that children might answer these questions in a lot of different ways, which is completely normal. We're just interested in what children of this age think.

parentTextBlock.text: Please point at each highlighted animal, name it, and explain to your child that it is in the category. For example, 'Look over here. This is a tuna. A tuna is a fish.
parentTextBlock.title: Parent's task

parentTextBlock.text: Please point at each highlighted animal, name it, and explain to your child that it is in the category. For example, 'Look over here. This is a guinea pig. A guinea pig is a mammal.'
parentTextBlock.title: Parent's task

parentTextBlock.text: Please point at each highlighted animal, name it, and explain to your child that it is in the category. For example, 'Look over here. This is a tiger snake. A tiger snake is a reptile.
parentTextBlock.title: Parent's task

parentTextBlock.text: Please point at each highlighted animal, name it, and explain to your child that it is in the category. For example, 'Look over here. This is a june beetle. A june beetle is an insect.
parentTextBlock.title: Parent's task

parentTextBlock.text: Please point at each highlighted animal, name it, and explain to your child that it is in the category. For example, 'Look over here. This is a tawny owl. A tawny owl is a bird of prey.
parentTextBlock.title: Parent's task

blocks.text: Thank you for participating in this study! Your child saw examples of concepts (e.g., examples of 'mammals' or 'reptiles'). However, there are better and worse examples to show a child if you want to teach them a new concept. For example, if you are trying to teach a toddler what a 'dog' is, showing them a Dalmatian, a Golden Retriever, a Beagle, and a Husky Dog is more useful than showing the four different Dalmatians. Here we were interested in parents' intuitions about the relationship between the examples and the concept, and their reaction to the misleading examples. In particular, we were interested in whether parents would spontaneously 'correct' the misleading examples by providing the child with additional examples. Thus, although the study was set up to look like an experiment on children's learning, we were actually interested in analyzing, not the children's performance on the questions asked, but adult behavior during the teaching portion of the tasks.

There were no right or wrong responses in this study. Parents were told to let the child respond on their own and not to interfere with any aspect of the experiment. If you let the study run without any deviation from the experiment design, that was a perfectly reasonable decision, and indeed what we'd asked you to do. However, in many studies, some parents do nonetheless 'interfere' with the design in one way or another. These participants are typically excluded from the analysis, but in this case, parental interference was the focus of the research. We believed parents might be more likely to 'interfere' with the study and point out additional examples of the concept in the trials where we gave the children misleading examples (e.g., showing only pets as examples of mammals, or only snakes as reptiles) than in the trials where we gave children representative examples (e.g., showing a snake, an iguana, a crocodile and a turtle as examples of reptiles). Investigating parents' responses to both 'good' and 'bad' instances of teaching can help us understand people's intuitive understanding of how the representativeness of examples affects learners' inferences. It can also help us understand the contexts in which parents might interfere with developmental studies, not because the parents are non-compliant, but because they are trying to support their child’s learning.

Thank you again for participating in this study. Developmental research would be impossible without parental support. Please note that you have the right to withdraw your data from the study if you wish. We'll be emailing you a $5 Amazon gift card. This should arrive in your inbox within the next week after we confirm that a child is with you in the video recording and check that your child is in the age range for this study. If you don't hear from us by then, feel free to reach out! Please don't hesitate to contact us at vivhan@mit.edu if you have any additional questions or feedback!

This project was inspired in part by Xu and Tenenbaum, 2007. In this paper, they show that when learning a new category, people use examples to figure out how broad or narrow the category is. Gweon et al. 2010 is another paper showing how different types of examples affect the conclusions infants draw. Also, check out https://www.randomlists.com/random-animals if you want to look at some more pictures of animals.
